I want the user to be able to put in either a function of 3 or 2 inputs, based on the coordinate system they choose, and I want to be able to convert one to the other in my function. If I run the following code

```if applicable(f, (0.3, 0.3, 0.1))
  g(x, y) = f(TernaryPlots.cart2tern(x,y)...)
else
   g(x, y) = f(x,y)
end

println(g(2,3))

LoadError: UndefVarError: g not defined```

elements.text: I want the user to be able to put in either a function of 3 or 2 inputs, based on the coordinate system they choose, and I want to be able to convert one to the other in my function. If I run the following code

if applicable(f, (0.3, 0.3, 0.1))
  g(x, y) = f(TernaryPlots.cart2tern(x,y)...)
else
   g(x, y) = f(x,y)
end

println(g(2,3))

LoadError: UndefVarError: g not defined

This model just doesn't fit with Julia as far as I understand it. E.g. it must be possible f could be (re)defined later. You can only define functions at global scope. You could generate a function from it;
but... having written this code just now, I certainly don't like it. So many issues with the approach at all I would reconsider the approach completely.
